pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:0.6: Homage to the Buddha, the Perfected One, the fully Awakened One
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:0.7: Venerables, these ninety-two rules on confession come up for recitation.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:1.2: At that time Hatthaka the Sakyan had been beaten in debate.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:1.3: While talking with the ascetics of other religions, he would assert things after denying them, and he would deny things after asserting them. He evaded the issues, lied, and made sham appointments.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:1.4: The ascetics of other religions complained and criticized him, “When Hatthaka talks with us, how can he assert things after denying them, deny things after asserting them, evade the issues, lie, and make sham appointments?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:1.5: The monks heard the complaints of those ascetics of other religions,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:1.6: and they went to Hatthaka and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:1.7: “Is it true, Hatthaka, that you’re acting like this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:1.8: “These ascetics of other religions should be beaten, whatever it takes!
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:1.9: They shouldn’t be allowed to win.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:1.10: The monks of few desires complained and criticized him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:1.11: “When Hatthaka talks with the ascetics of other religions, how can he assert things after denying them, deny things after asserting them, evade the issues, lie, and make sham appointments?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:1.12: After rebuking Hatthaka in many ways, they told the Buddha.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:1.13: Soon afterwards the Buddha had the Sangha gathered and questioned Hatthaka:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:1.14: “Is it true, Hatthaka, that you’re acting like this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:1.17: “… Foolish man, when you talk with the ascetics of other religions, how can you assert things after denying them, deny things after asserting them, evade the issues, lie, and make sham appointments?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:1.18: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:1.19: And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:1.20.1: ‘If a monk lies in full awareness, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:2.1.2: the speech of one who is aiming to deceive—his words, his way of speaking, his breaking into speech, his verbal expression, his eight kinds of ignoble speech: he says that he has seen what he has not seen; he says that he has heard what he has not heard; he says that he has sensed what he has not sensed; he says that he has known what he has not known; he says that he has not seen what he has seen; he says that he has not heard what he has heard; he says that he has not sensed what he has sensed; he says that he has not known what he has known.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:2.1.8: not smelled with the nose, not tasted with the tongue, not touched with the body.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:2.1.16: smelled with the nose, tasted with the tongue, touched with the body.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:2.2.0.2: Falsely claiming to have experienced what he has not experienced: a single sense door
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:2.2.1: If he lies in full awareness, saying that he has seen what he has not seen, he commits an offense entailing confession when three conditions are fulfilled:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:2.2.2: before he has lied, he knows he is going to lie; while lying, he knows he is lying; after he has lied, he knows he has lied.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1:2.2.4: before he has lied, he knows he is going to lie; while lying, he knows he is lying; after he has lied, he knows he has lied; in misrepresenting his view of what is true.
